body:
Whilst conditions on sanitizer definition would be cool, your case can be addressed easier :-)

`htmlspecialchars` is already defined as sanitizer for `TaintedHtml`: 

https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/blob/3943b55f8a0f33de3d4a107888a74ed82ee338d8/stubs/CoreGenericFunctions.phpstub#L662

The reason that you get the results that you get, is that you haven't annotated the function with `psalm-pure` (https://psalm.dev/docs/security_analysis/avoiding_false_positives/).

Check https://psalm.dev/r/307ed9c3f7
Wait. I am wrong. Pure doesn't help here :/  - That seems indeed like something that should be addressed in Psalm, I could see something like this as a common pattern.

> Wait. I am wrong. Pure doesn't help here :/

Hmm, why are you wrong? It seems the error is correctly gone for the first function call.

@gharlan, because it would still trigger if there's only one of them: https://psalm.dev/r/ad0a0afd0f. 

On a general note, something like the return conditional support would be helpful to have for taint / sink / sanitizer sources indeed. There's quite some cases where functions become harmless if passed the right values. So I can see the value.

issue.body:
## Scenario

```
/**
 * @param string $value
 * @param bool $isSecure
 *
 * @psalm-taint-sink shell $value
 * @psalm-taint-escape ($isSecure is true ? 'shell' : null)
 */
function doThat(string $value, bool $isSecure = false): void {}

doThat((string)($_GET['value'] ?? ''), true);
```

* this function (stub) is supposed hand over `$value` to some shell invocation
* thus, in general `$value` is insecure and *tainted shell code*
* however, in case `$isSecure` is true, it shall be considered as secure

## References

* https://psalm.dev/r/2ed94669f3
* follow-up to issue #4661 and commit https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/commit/af008953a8022566477b0555a10e17dac58e6a2f
